I’ve spent my career advocating for workers’ rights, effective worker training programs and an equitable education system, and I’m thrilled to continue that work as a member of the Education and Labor Committee. (6/6)
My primary focus as the congressman from Michigan’s 9th District is to help rebuild the middle class by making every policy decision about raising the standard of living for working people. (5/6)
The skyrocketing cost of higher education is making it harder for parents to send their kids to college, and college graduates who have paid their way face immense burdens of debt. (4/6)

Our students in K-12 schools are not getting the resources they need to be successful, and policymakers are not listening to the educators and specialists who work hands-on with students every day. (3/6)
Despite a lifetime of hard work, most older Americans don’t have the savings to retire with dignity. Our economy isn’t working for all Americans as real wages are stagnant. (2/6)
I came to Congress to tackle the big problems that are keeping working families from prospering. (1/6)

Allowing discrimination and harassment to go unchecked can have serious consequences on the lives and careers of those who are interested in government service.

This bill will give federal interns the same protections already provided to federal employees. This is a great start, but more must be done. I urge my colleagues to also support the Unpaid Intern Protection Act, which would give interns outside of government similar protections.

The act of harassing unpaid interns on the basis of race, religion, age, or sex is not currently prohibited by federal law. Under existing law, victims rely on the discretion and integrity of managers to prevent this behavior.

I am pleased that the House passed my bill, the Federal Intern Protection Act, to close a loophole in federal employment law that currently leaves unpaid interns open to discrimination and sexual harassment without any legal recourse.

https://www.rollcall.com/news/congress/house-moves-protect-federal-interns-harassment-discrimination

I look forward to leading important work in the House of Representatives to reaffirm our NATO membership and am confident that oversight over President Trump's impulsive decisions on this critical security issue will be vigorously pursued here in Congress.

Withdrawing from NATO would create one of the most dangerous security voids of our lifetimes serving only to empower those who would strive to weaken the United States and undermine the world order the we have spent the last half of the twentieth century building with our allies.

NATO is a cornerstone of our efforts to keep Americans safe here at home and let us not forget that NATO Article 5 has only been invoked once in its history - in the collective defense of the United States after 9/11.

The President's willingness to discard our longstanding NATO alliance without consulting Congress or our allies is disturbing. That there was discussion of this prospect alone is alarming, damages our credibility with our European allies, and leaves us less secure.
